label: BODY

text: Here we go again, La
label: H4

text: Niña is coming back for
label: H4

text: an encore performance,
label: H4

text: just like in 2008, 1999,
label: H4

text: ECMWF forecast from May 2011(left):
label: H4

text: Correct anticipation of warm-up through
label: H4

text: June, but missed the reappearance of La
label: H4

text: Niña conditions after that;
label: H4

text: A not-yet published paper that has evaluated
label: H4

text: every model over the last decade has
label: H4

text: confirmed that ECMWF is the ‘gold
label: H4

text: standard’ in this business.
label: H4

text: The most recent forecast (right) shows
label: HH3

text: moderate La Niña conditions this
label: H4

text: winter, with no chance of El Niño or
label: H4

text: even ENSO-neutral before February
label: H4

text: 2011 (left):     Transition to ENSO-
label: H4

text: neutral by early summer (√), then
label: H4

text: wide open outcome  for rest of 2011;
label: H4

text: On average, dynamical models a bit
label: H4

text: warmer than statistical models,
label: H4

text: insignificant differences overall.
label: H4

text: The most recent forecast collection
label: HH3

text: (right) shows a shift towards La Niña,
label: H4

text: although only half of the models reach
label: H4

text: the ‘magic’ -0.5C threshold; meanwhile,
label: H4

label: H4

text: remains negative, having proven itself
label: H4

text: yet again to be consistent with the return
label: H4

text: of La Niña...

text: Climate Prediction Center ‘Analog’ Forecasts
label: H2

text: According to yesterday’s soil-moisture analog forecast, wet anomalies are favored in
label: HH3

text: northernmost CO along with cooler-than-average temperatures, while drought conditions
label: H4

text: remain anchored towards the Four Corners and northern TX.  Typical skill at this lead-
label: H4

text: time (right) is quite high over northeast CO where there is a tilt towards wet conditions.
label: H4

text: Source: http://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/soilmst/cas.shtml
label: BODY

text: Climate Prediction Center ‘Analog’ Forecasts
label: H2

text: According to yesterday’s soil-moisture analog forecast, dry conditions threaten eastern CO
label: HH3

text: in late winter, while our mountains may look forward to a near-normal winter.  Typical
label: H4

text: skill at this long lead-time (right) is high to our south, maintaining drought conditions from
label: H4

text: eastern NM and most of TX up into SE CO.
label: H4

text: Source: http://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/soilmst/cas.shtml

text: Climate Prediction Center Forecasts
label: H2

text: CPC’s Oct-Dec (left) temperature forecast expects a warm fall
label: HH3

text: (La Niña+trend), especially in already dry eastern CO. Their
label: H4

text: precipitation forecast (right) keeps it dry for all of us, again,
label: H4

text: consistent with La Niña-based expectations, and some composites
label: H4

text: that I made for 2nd year La Niña conditions.
label: H4

text: Source: http://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/predictions/
label: H4

text: Climate Prediction Center Forecasts
label: H2

text: CPC’s Jan-Mar ‘12 (left) temperature forecast expects
label: HH3

text: Colorado to straddle warm anomalies to the south and cold
label: H4

text: anomalies to the north. A similar picture transpires for
label: H4

text: precipitation (wet to the north, dry to the south), again,
label: H4

text: consistent with La Niña-based expectations (and my composite).
label: H4

text: Source: http://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/predictions/

text: Statistical Forecast for April-June 2011
label: H3

text: February’s (top left), March’s (top middle), and
label: HH3

text: April’s (top right) forecasts for April-June 2011
label: H4

text: were fairly confident that southern CO would see
label: H4

text: below-normal moisture.  The northwestern third of
label: H4

text: our state had slightly increased chances of being
label: H4

text: wetter-than-average.
label: H4

text: Most of southern CO ended up dry, and northwest
label: H4

text: CO wet (right).  On the other hand, the northeast
label: H4

text: corner of our state was wetter than expected, ditto
label: H4

text: for the Four Corners region.  IOW, the February
label: H4

text: forecast panned out better than later updates (also
label: H4

text: for New Mexico)!
label: H4

text: Statistical Forecast for July-September 2011
label: HH2

text: The April forecast for July-September 2011 (left) was
label: HH3

text: optimistic for northwestern CO, and undecided for the
label: H4

text: rest of the state.  The June forecast (top right) was
label: H4

text: significantly drier, including my 1st dry summer forecast
label: H4

text: for the eastern plains in more than one decade.
label: H4

text: As of yesterday (right), dry conditions have indeed
label: H4

text: prevailed in much of eastern CO, especially in the
label: H4

text: Arkansas Valley which was already under drought
label: H4

text: conditions. Early July wetness (plus a couple of storms this
label: H4

text: month) have kept us (FR) wetter than expected.
label: H4

text: Statistical Forecast for Oct-Dec 2011
label: H3

text: My new forecast for October-December 2011 (left) is leaning towards dry conditions over
label: HH3

text: southern and eastern CO, leaving the West slope and mountains under climatological odds.
label: H4

text: Verification statistics over the last decade (right) show skill over the dry northeastern plains
label: H4

text: of CO, but not to the west.
label: H4

text: Statistical Forecast for January-March 2012
label: HH2

text: My new forecast for January-March 2012 (left) is leaning towards dry conditions over
label: HH3

text: southeastern CO, again leaving the mountains under climatological odds, and the far
label: H4

text: western valleys and Four-Corners’ region with a slight tilt towards a dry late winter.
label: H4

text: Verification statistics over the last decade (right) show skill for much of the domain, except
label: H4

text: the higher elevations of CO.
label: H4

text: Last year (no forecast issued), my forecast for JFM’11 would have been dry for eastern CO,
label: H4

text: and at least near-normal for the mountains.
label: H4

text: Executive Summary (22 September 2011) – klaus.wolter@noaa.gov
label: HH2

text: La Niña appears to be making a come-back, confirming my long-lead statements from
label: H4

text: last October.  It probably will end up weaker than last winter, but that is less
label: H4

text: important for impacts than in the El Niño case.
label: H4

text: 2.    The last three months did not see much of a flooding season (√), a late run-off season (no
label: H4

text: excessive dust √), and a less severe fire season than feared.  All in all, Colorado did very
label: H4

text: well last Water Year, with (near-)record snowpack conditions coming off in the most
label: H4

text: benign manner possible.
label: H4

text: Along the Front Range, the monsoon season was wetter-than-expected, with a
label: H4

text: particularly wet start in July, but severe dryness in August.  Those rains of early July
label: H4

text: may have involved recycled moisture from our record-snowpack, IMHO.  The next two
label: H4

text: weeks will see a return of dry/mild conditions, with no prospects for snow (or rain)
label: H4

text: before September is over.
label: H4

text: My forecast for the next six months is not optimistic, especially for southeastern
label: H4

text: Colorado.  Thanks to La Niña, the mountains have a good chance of getting close to
label: H4

text: normal snowfall in mid-winter (to be firmed up in next two months).  A repeat of last
label: H4

text: year’s record-breaking snows is unlikely.
label: H4

text: Bottomline (Double-Dip La Niña): In our state, 2nd year La Niña winter half-years are
label: H4

text: often drier than in the previous year.  There is little evidence that would support a
label: H4

text: contrary (wet) viewpoint.  This statement does not factor in ‘rogue atmospheric river
label: H4

text: events’ (like last December) that are currently not predictable at the seasonal time-scale.
label: H4
